  • Built-in Filters

Built-in Filters

Define Soft Delete Flag​

Jimmer supports logical delete, for example

  • Java
  • Kotlin
Book.java
@Entity
public interface Book {

    @LogicalDeleted(
        value = "true",
        useMultiViewCache = true
    )
    boolean isDeleted();

    ...other code omitted...
}
Book.kt
@Entity
interface Book {

    @LogicalDeleted(
        value = "true",
        useMultiViewCache = true
    )
    val isDeleted: Boolean

    ...other code omitted...
}

Logical delete is actually a built-in global filter in Jimmer, so the Book entity is applied with a global filter.

Once an entity has a global filter, the following properties

  • Association properties that target Book. For example, BookStore.books, Author.books

  • Computed properties that depend on the above association properties. For example, BookStore.avgPrice, BookStore.newestBooks

will be sensitive to the filter and show different data to different clients due to different filtering behaviors.

These filter-sensitive properties either do not support caching or support multi-view caching.

caution

The useMultiViewCache = true in the above code is very important.

The default value is false, which means all filter-sensitive properties (BookStore.books, Author.books, BookStore.avgPrice, and BookStore.newestBooks) do NOT support caching. This is a conservative option.

To make these properties cacheable (of course they must also support multi-view properties), you must configure useMultiViewCache = true.

Enable Multi-view Cache​

Normal Approach​

  • Java
  • Kotlin
@Bean
public CacheFactory cacheFactory(
    RedisConnectionFactory connectionFactory,
    ObjectMapper objectMapper
) {

    RedisTemplate<String, byte[]> redisTemplate = 
        RedisCaches.cacheRedisTemplate(connectionFactory);

    return new CacheFactory() {

        @Override
        public Cache<?, ?> createObjectCache(@NotNull ImmutableType type) {
            ...code omitted...
        }

        @Override
        public Cache<?, ?> createAssociatedIdCache(@NotNull ImmutableProp prop) {
            ...code omitted...
        }

        @Override
        public Cache<?, ?> createAssociatedIdCache(@NotNull ImmutableProp prop) {
            return createPropCache(
                prop == BookStoreProps.BOOKS.unwrap() || 
                    prop == AuthorProps.BOOKS.unwrap()
                prop, 
                Duration.ofMinutes(5)
            );
        }

        @Override
        public Cache<?, ?> createResolverCache(ImmutableProp prop) {
            return createPropCache(
                prop == BookStoreProps.AVG_PRICE.unwrap() || 
                    prop == BookStoreProps.NEWEST_BOOKS.unwrap()
                prop, 
                Duration.ofHours(1)
            );
        }

        private <K, V> Cache<K, V> createPropCache(
            boolean isMultiviewCache,
            ImmutableProp prop, 
            Duration duration
        ) {
            if (isMultiView) {
                return new ChainCacheBuilder<K, V>()
                        .add(
                            new RedisHashBinder<>(
                                redisTemplate, 
                                objectMapper, 
                                prop, 
                                redisDuration
                            )
                        )
                        .build();
            }

            return new ChainCacheBuilder<>()
                .add(
                    new CaffeineBinder<>(512, Duration.ofSeconds(1))
                )
                .add(
                    new RedisValueBinder<>(
                        redisTemplate, 
                        objectMapper, 
                        prop, 
                        duration
                    )
                )
                .build();
        }
    };
}
@Bean  
fun cacheFactory(
    connectionFactory: RedisConnectionFactory,
    objectMapper: ObjectMapper
): KCacheFactory {

    val redisTemplate = RedisCaches.cacheRedisTemplate(connectionFactory)

    return object: KCacheFactory {

        override fun createObjectCache(type: ImmutableType): Cache<*, *>? =
            ...code omitted...

        override fun createAssociatedIdCache(prop: ImmutableProp): Cache<*, *>? =
            ...code omitted...

        override fun createAssociatedIdListCache(prop: ImmutableProp): Cache<*, List<*>>? =
            createPropCache(
                prop === BookStore::books.toImmutableProp() ||
                    prop === Author::books.toImmutableProp(),
                prop,
                Duration.ofHours(1)
            )

        override fun createResolverCache(prop: ImmutableProp): Cache<*, *> =
            createPropCache(
                prop === BookStore::avgPrice.toImmutableProp() ||
                    prop === BookStore::newestBooks.toImmutableProp(),
                prop,
                Duration.ofHours(1)
            )

        private fun <K, V> createPropCache(
            isMultiView: Boolean,
            prop: ImmutableProp, 
            duration: Duration
        ): Cache<K, V> {
            if (isMultiView) {
                return ChainCacheBuilder<K, V>()
                        .add(
                            RedisHashBinder<>(
                                redisTemplate, 
                                objectMapper, 
                                prop, 
                                redisDuration
                            )
                        )
                        .build();
            }
            ChainCacheBuilder<Any, Any>()
                .add(
                    CaffeineBinder(512, Duration.ofSeconds(1))
                )
                .add(
                    RedisValueBinder(
                        redisTemplate, 
                        objectMapper, 
                        prop, 
                        duration
                    )
                )
                .build()
        }
    }
}

The RedisHashBinder class in the above code is a very important implementation that utilizes Redis' support for multi-view caching. The underlying storage structure corresponds to Redis Hashes, i.e. nested Hash structures.

Cache StyleMulti-viewAbstract API❶Built-in Impl❷
Cache with self-loading
(usually first-level cache technologies like Guava, Caffine)
NoLoadingBinder<K, V>CaffeineBinder<K, V>
YesLoadingBinder.Parameterized<K, V>None
Cache without self-loading
(usually second-level cache technologies like Redis)
NoSimpleBinder<K, V>RedisValueBinder<K, V>
YesSimpleBinder.Parameterized<K, V>RedisHashBinder<K, V>

  • ❶ Abstract API: located in project jimmer-sql, package org.babyfish.jimmer.sql.cache.chain

  • ❷ Built-in implementations: located in project jimmer-spring-boot-starter, package org.babyfish.jimmer.spring.cache

caution

Unfortunately, there is currently no multi-view cache implementation for Caffeine. So in the above code, multi-view caching only applies to Redis. That is, in multi-view mode, there is only one cache level instead of two.

Better Approach​

In the above code, the createAssociatedIdListCache method judges the prop parameter to decide whether to build multi-view cache or single-view cache. However,

tip

For association properties, whether multi-view cache needs to be built can be determined solely by whether the target entity is filtered. Jimmer provides better support for this.

Developers only need to replace the super interface CacheFactory/KCacheFactory with the super class AbstractCacheFactory/AbstractKCacheFactory to inherit a member called getFilterState/filterState which can help us determine whether to build multi-view cache.

  • Java
  • Kotlin
@Bean
public CacheFactory cacheFactory(
    RedisConnectionFactory connectionFactory,
    ObjectMapper objectMapper  
) {

    RedisTemplate<String, byte[]> redisTemplate = 
        RedisCaches.cacheRedisTemplate(connectionFactory);

    return new AbstractCacheFactory() {

        @Override
        public Cache<?, ?> createObjectCache(@NotNull ImmutableType type) {
            ...code omitted...
        }

        @Override
        public Cache<?, ?> createAssociatedIdCache(@NotNull ImmutableProp prop) {
            return createPropCache(
                getFilterState().isAffectedBy(prop.getTargetType()),
                prop, 
                Duration.ofMinutes(5)
            );
        }

        @Override
        public Cache<?, ?> createAssociatedIdCache(@NotNull ImmutableProp prop) {
            return createPropCache(
                getFilterState().isAffectedBy(prop.getTargetType()),
                prop, 
                Duration.ofMinutes(5)
            );
        }

        @Override
        public Cache<?, ?> createResolverCache(ImmutableProp prop) {
            return createPropCache(
                prop == BookStoreProps.AVG_PRICE.unwrap() ||
                    prop == BookStoreProps.NEWEST_BOOKS.unwrap()
                prop, 
                Duration.ofHours(1)
            );
        }

        private <K, V> Cache<K, V> createPropCache(
            boolean isMultiviewCache,
            ImmutableProp prop, 
            Duration duration
        ) {
            ...code omitted...
        }
    };
}
@Bean
fun cacheFactory(  
    connectionFactory: RedisConnectionFactory,
    objectMapper: ObjectMapper
): KCacheFactory {

    val redisTemplate = RedisCaches.cacheRedisTemplate(connectionFactory)

    return object: AbstractKCacheFactory() {

        override fun createObjectCache(type: ImmutableType): Cache<*, *>? =
            ...code omitted...    

        override fun createAssociatedIdCache(prop: ImmutableProp): Cache<*, *>? =
            ...code omitted...

        override fun createAssociatedIdListCache(prop: ImmutableProp): Cache<*, List<*>>? =
            createPropCache(
                filterState.isAffectedBy(prop.targetType),
                prop,
                Duration.ofHours(1)
            )

        override fun createResolverCache(prop: ImmutableProp): Cache<*, *> =
            createPropCache(
                filterState.isAffectedBy(prop.targetType),
                prop,
                Duration.ofHours(1)
            )

        private fun <K, V> createPropCache(
            isMultiView: Boolean,
            prop: ImmutableProp, 
            duration: Duration
        ): Cache<K, V> {
            ...code omitted...
        }
    }
}
caution

Unfortunately, this method can only simplify the construction of association caches, i.e. simplify the createAssociatedIdCache and createAssociatedIdListCache methods.

For computed properties, since the framework is unaware of the internal logic used by user-defined computed properties, it cannot simplify them. Users need to decide whether to build multi-view caches based on their own business characteristics.

SubKey of Computed Properties​

Logical delete is a built-in filter, and all affected association properties will automatically specify SubKey for their association caches.

However, unfortunately, due to the introduction of user-defined computation rules that the framework cannot understand, developers must manually specify SubKey for the Resolver implementation of computed properties.

  • Java
  • Kotlin
BookStoreAvgPriceResolver.java
@Component
public class BookStoreAvgPriceResolver implements TransientResolver<Long, BigDecimal> {
    
    private final JSqlClient sqlClient;

    @Override
    public Ref<SortedMap<String, Object>> getParameterMapRef() {
        return sqlClient
            .getFilters()
            .getTargetParameterMapRef(BookStoreProps.BOOKS);
    }

    ...other code omitted...
}
BookStoreAvgPriceResolver.kt
@Compoent
class BookStoreAvgPriceResolver(
    private val sqlClient: KSqlClient
) : KTransientResolver<Long, BigDecimal> {

    override fun getParameterMapRef(): Ref<SortedMap<String, Any>?>? {
        return sqlClient
            .filters
            .getTargetParameterMapRef(BookStore::books)
    }

    ...other code omitted... 
}

Obviously, the computed property BookStore.avgPrice is actually determined by the association property BookStore.books and changes with it.

Therefore, whatever SubKey the association property BookStore.books specifies for the multi-view cache system in the current invocation context, the computed property BookStore.avgPrice should specify the same one.

note

BookStore.avgPrice is also affected by Book.price. It changes when Book.price changes.

However, Book.price is a non-association property of the object, so it is irrelevant to the multi-view cache system. The getParameterMapRef method does not need to consider it here.

Usage​

Normal Usage​

Now that we have made the association property BookStore.books and the computed property BookStore.avgPrice support multi-view caching, let's use object fetchers to query them

  • Java
  • Kotlin
BookStoreTable table = BookStoreTable.$;
List<BookStore> stores = sqlClient
    .createQuery(table)
    .select(
        table.fetch(
            BookStoreFetcher.$
                .allScalarFields()
                .books( ❶
                    BookFetcher.$
                        .allScalarFields()
                )
                .avgPrice() ❷
        )
    )
    .execute();
System.out.println(stores); 
val stores = sqlClient
    .createQuery(BookStore::class) {
        select(
            table.fetchBy {
                allScalarFields()
                books { ❶
                    allScalarFields()
                }
                avgPrice() ❷
            }
        )
    }
    .execute()
println(stores)

  • Step 1: Query the aggregate root

    First query the aggregate root objects by executing the following SQL

    select
        tb_1_.ID,
        tb_1_.NAME,
        tb_1_.WEBSITE 
    from BOOK_STORE tb_1_

    This implements the query in the code and obtains some BookStore objects. Such objects directly queried by users are called aggregate root objects.

    caution

    Jimmer does NOT cache the returned aggregate objects queried by users because the consistency of such query results cannot be guaranteed. Even if caching them at the cost of sacrificing consistency is required, it should be handled by users as a business problem rather than an behavior that should be abstracted and unified by the framework.

  • Step 2: Query BookStore.books ❶ via association cache

    The above code will obtain a list of aggregate root objects. If using the official sample data, it will get two aggregate root objects with ID of 1 and 2.

    Jimmer first looks up the data in Redis with keys BookStore.books-1 and BookStore.books-2.

    Assuming the data for these keys cannot be found in Redis

    127.0.0.1:6379> keys BookStore.books-*
    (empty array)

    Then the following SQL is executed to resolve the association property BookStore.books

    select
        tb_1_.STORE_ID,
        tb_1_.ID
    from BOOK tb_1_  
    where
            tb_1_.STORE_ID in (
                ? /* 1 */, ? /* 2 */  
            )
        and
            tb_1_.DELETED = ? /* false */
    order by
        tb_1_.NAME asc, 
        tb_1_.EDITION desc
    info

    The filtering condition tb_1_.DELETED = false comes from the implicit built-in filter of the logical delete feature.

    Jimmer will put the query results into Redis, so we can view the data in redis:

    127.0.0.1:6379> keys BookStore.books-*  
    1) "BookStore.books-2"
    2) "BookStore.books-1"

    127.0.0.1:6379> hgetall BookStore.books-1
    # highlight-next-line  
    1) "{\"logicalDeleted\":false}"
    2) "[6,5,3,2,9,8]"

    127.0.0.1:6379> hgetall BookStore.books-2
    # highlight-next-line
    1) "{\"logicalDeleted\":false}" 
    2) "[12,11]"
    info

    The multi-view cache uses Redis Hash structure, so the hgetall command of redis is needed instead of simple get.

    Redis Hash is a nested two-layer KV structure.

    • The outer layer Redis Key like BookStore.books-1 and BookStore.books-2 is no different from keys in single-view cache.

    • The inner layer Hash Key, also called SubKey in Jimmer, is the parameter of global filters.

      Here, {"logicalDeleted":false} is provided by the built-in global filter of logical delete, indicating the cached value is not the collection of ids of all associated objects, but only the ids of those undeleted associated objects.

    tip

    Undoubtedly, if the cached data in Redis is not cleared due to timeout, executing the above Java/Kotlin code again will directly return the association data from Redis without generating related SQL.

  • Step 3: Convert id collection to associated objects

    In the previous step, we obtained the collection of ids of the associated objects corresponding to the association property BookStore.books. They are all undeleted objects.

    Now we can use the object cache of Book type to convert the Book id collection to Book collection.

    This step is very simple and needs no discussion.

    • Step 4: Query BookStore.avgPrice ❷ via computed cache

    The above code will obtain a list of aggregate root objects. If using the official sample data, there will be two aggregate root objects with ID of 1 and 2.

    Jimmer first looks up the data in Redis with keys BookStore.avgPrice-1 and BookStore.avgPrice-2.

    Assuming the data for these keys cannot be found in Redis

    127.0.0.1:6379> keys BookStore.avgPrice-* 
    (empty array)

    Then the following SQL is executed to compute the calculated property

    select 
        tb_1_.ID,
        avg(tb_2_.PRICE)
    from BOOK_STORE tb_1_
    left join BOOK tb_2_
        on tb_1_.ID = tb_2_.STORE_ID
    where
            tb_1_.ID in (
                ? /* 1 */, ? /* 2 */  
            )
        and
            tb_1_.DELETED = ? /* false */
    group by 
        tb_1_.ID
    info

    The filtering condition tb_1_.DELETED = false comes from the built-in global filter of logical delete.

    Jimmer will put the query results into Redis, so we can view the data in Redis:

    127.0.0.1:6379> keys BookStore.avgPrice-*
    1) "BookStore.avgPrice-2"  
    2) "BookStore.avgPrice-1"

    127.0.0.1:6379> hgetall BookStore.avgPrice-1
    1) "{\"logicalDeleted\":false}"
    2) "59.333333"

    127.0.0.1:6379> hgetall BookStore.avgPrice-2
    1) "{\"logicalDeleted\":false}"
    2) "80.5" 
    127.0.0.1:6379>
    info

    The multi-view cache uses Redis Hash structure, so the hgetall command is needed instead of get.

    Redis Hash is a nested two-layer KV structure.

    • The outer layer Redis Key like BookStore.avgPrice-1 and BookStore.avgPrice-2 is no different from keys in single-view cache.

    • The inner layer Hash Key, also called SubKey in Jimmer, is the parameter of global filters.

    Here, {"logicalDeleted":false} is provided by the built-in global filter of logical delete, indicating the cached value depends on the undeleted associated data rather than all associated data.

    Thus, the two BookStore objects can obtain the average prices of their respective undeleted books via the computed property BookStore.avgPrice.

    tip

    Undoubtedly, if the cached data in Redis is not cleared due to timeout, executing the above Java/Kotlin code again will directly return the computed data from Redis without generating related SQL.

Finally, Jimmer concatenates the results of the 4 steps as the final data returned to the user.

[
    {
        "id":1,
        "name":"O'REILLY",
        "website":null,
        "books":[
            {
                "id":6,
                "name":"Effective TypeScript", 
                "edition":3,
                "price":88
            },
            {
                "id":5,
                ...omitted...
            },
            {
                "id":3,
                ...omitted...
            },
            {
                "id":2,
                ...omitted...
            },
            {
                "id":9,
                ...omitted...
            },
            {
                "id":8,
                ...omitted...
            }
        ],
        "avgPrice":59.333333,
    },
    {
        "id":2,
        "name":"MANNING",
        "website":null,
        "books":[
            {
                "id":12,
                "name":"GraphQL in Action",
                "edition":3,
                "price":80
            },
            {
                "id":11,
                ...omitted...
            }
        ],
        "avgPrice":80.5
    }
]

Adjust Filtering Behavior​

In the Logical Delete documentation, we introduced that the logical delete filter can be ignored or even reversed.

  • Ignore filtering behavior

    • Java
    • Kotlin
    BookTable table = BookTable.$;

    List<Book> books = sqlClient
        .filters(cfg -> {
            cfg.disable(
                cfg
                    .getFilterManager()
                    .builtIns()
                    .getDeclaredNotDeletedFilter(Book.class)
            ); 
        })
        .createQuery(table)
        .select(table)
        .execute();
    val books = sqlClient
        .filters {
            disable(
                filterManager
                    .builtIns
                    .getDeclaredNotDeletedFilter(Book::class)
            )
        }
        .createQuery(table)
        .select(table)
        .execute()

    After executing the code, if the cached information entered in the previous example has not been cleared, the latest data in Redis should be:

    127.0.0.1:6379> keys BookStore.books-*
    1) "BookStore.books-2"
    2) "BookStore.books-1"

    127.0.0.1:6379> hgetall BookStore.books-1
    1) "{\"logicalDeleted\":false}"
    2) "[6,5,3,2,9,8]"
    3) "{}"
    4) "[6,5,4,3,2,1,9,8,7]"

    127.0.0.1:6379> hgetall BookStore.books-2
    1) "{\"logicalDeleted\":false}"
    2) "[12,11]" 
    3) "{}"
    4) "[12,11,10]"

    127.0.0.1:6379> keys BookStore.avgPrice-*
    1) "BookStore.avgPrice-2"
    2) "BookStore.avgPrice-1"

    127.0.0.1:6379> hgetall BookStore.avgPrice-1
    1) "{\"logicalDeleted\":false}"
    2) "59.333333"
    3) "{}"
    4) "58.5"

    127.0.0.1:6379> hgetall BookStore.avgPrice-2 
    1) "{\"logicalDeleted\":false}"
    2) "80.5"
    3) "{}"
    4) "8.333333"

    • The outer layer Redis Keys like BookStore.books-1, BookStore.books-2, BookStore.avgPrice-1 and BookStore.avgPrice-2 are no different from keys in single-view cache.

    • The inner layer Hash Keys, also called SubKeys in Jimmer, are the parameters of global filters.

      {} is the corresponding SubKey for this example, and the corresponding cached value is the data when the filter is ignored. This is also what we see in the documentation about single-view cache.

  • Reverse filtering behavior

    • Java
    • Kotlin
    BookTable table = BookTable.$;

    List<Book> books = sqlClient
        .filters(cfg -> {
            cfg.disable(
                cfg
                    .getFilterManager()
                    .builtIns()
                    .getDeclaredNotDeletedFilter(Book.class)
            );
            cfg.enable(
                cfg
                    .getFilterManager()
                    .builtIns()
                    .getDeclaredAlreadyDeletedFilter(Book.class)
            );
        })
        .createQuery(table)
        .select(table)
        .execute();
    val books = sqlClient
        .filters {
            disable(
                filterManager
                    .builtIns
                    .getDeclaredNotDeletedFilter(Book::class)
            )
            enable(
                cfg
                    .getFilterManager()
                    .builtIns()
                    .getDeclaredAlreadyDeletedFilter(Book.class)
            )
        }
        .createQuery(table)
        .select(table)
        .execute()

    After executing the code, if the cached information entered in the previous example has not been cleared, the latest data in Redis should be:

    127.0.0.1:6379> keys BookStore.books-*
    1) "BookStore.books-2"
    2) "BookStore.books-1"

    127.0.0.1:6379> hgetall BookStore.books-1
    1) "{}"
    2) "[6,5,4,3,2,1,9,8,7]"
    3) "{\"logicalDeleted\":false}"
    4) "[6,5,3,2,9,8]"
    5) "{\"logicalDeleted\":true}"
    6) "[4,1,7]"

    127.0.0.1:6379> hgetall BookStore.books-2
    1) "{}"
    2) "[12,11,10]"
    3) "{\"logicalDeleted\":false}"
    4) "[12,11]"
    5) "{\"logicalDeleted\":true}"
    6) "[10]"

    127.0.0.1:6379> keys BookStore.avgPrice-*
    1) "BookStore.avgPrice-2"
    2) "BookStore.avgPrice-1"

    127.0.0.1:6379> hgetall BookStore.avgPrice-1
    3) "{}"
    4) "58.5"
    1) "{\"logicalDeleted\":false}"
    2) "59.333333" 
    1) "{\"logicalDeleted\":true}"
    2) "56.833333"

    127.0.0.1:6379> hgetall BookStore.avgPrice-2
    3) "{}"
    4) "8.333333"
    1) "{\"logicalDeleted\":false}"
    2) "80.5"
    1) "{\"logicalDeleted\":true}"
    2) "80"

    • The outer layer Redis Keys like BookStore.books-1, BookStore.books-2, BookStore.avgPrice-1 and BookStore.avgPrice-2 are no different from keys in single-view cache.

    • The inner layer Hash Keys, also called SubKeys in Jimmer, are the parameters of global filters.

      {"logicalDeleted":true} is the corresponding SubKey for this example, indicating the cached value depends on the deleted associated data rather than all associated data, which is the opposite of the default filtering logic.

    tip

    Readers can take a close look at these redis-cli commands and easily find that the data of SubKey {"logicalDeleted":false} merged with the data of SubKey {"logicalDeleted":true} is exactly the data of SubKey {}.

Consistency​

Now let's modify the logical delete flag of the Book object with id 6.

Since Book-6 belongs to BookStore-1, it is foreseeable that the multi-view caches corresponding to the properties BookStore.books-1 and BookStore.avgPrice-1 will definitely be invalidated.

  • If BinLog trigger is enabled, modifying the database in any way can lead to Jimmer's cache consistency involvement. For example, directly executing the following SQL in SQL IDE

    update BOOK  
    set DELETED = true
    where ID = 6;

  • If only Transaction trigger is enabled, the database must be modified using Jimmer's API

    • Java
    • Kotlin
    sqlClient.deleteById(Book.class, 6L, DeleteMode.LOGICAL)
    sqlClient.deleteById(Book::class, 6L, DeleteMode.LOGICAL)
    info

    Since the Book entity is configured with a logical delete field, the default delete policy is logical delete. So the DeleteMode.LOGICAL above can actually be omitted. It is written explicitly here just for emphasis.

No matter which way above is used to modify the data, you will see the following log output:

Delete data from redis: [Book-6] ❶
Delete data from redis: [Author.books-3] ❷
Delete data from redis: [BookStore.books-1] ❸
Delete data from redis: [BookStore.avgPrice-1] ❹

  • ❶ Update object cache of modified entity

  • ❷ Any association property targeting Book must be affected, of course including Author.books

    According to existing database data, the affected Author object id is 3

  • ❸ Any association property targeting Book must be affected, of course including BookStore.books

    According to existing database data, the affected BookStore object id is 1

  • ❹ The computed cache BookStore.avgPrice of BookStore object with id 1 is also affected. This is the most amazing characteristic.

    If you have forgotten the specific logic of this code, you can review the following code in the Computed Cache documentation:

    • Kotlin
    @EventListener
    fun onAssociationChange(e: AssociationEvent) {
        if (sqlClient.caches.isAffectedBy(e) && 
            e.isChanged(BookStore::books)
        ) {
            ...code omitted...
        }
    }

    If you focus on the highlighted line, this computed property cares about changes to the association property BookStore.books.

    tip

    Modifying the association field between tables is not the only way to trigger association change events. Modifying the filtered field in associated objects, like DELETED here, can also trigger association change events.

    This is a very important characteristic of Jimmer's trigger mechanism!

    It is obvious that ❸ has already sensed the change of association property BookStore.books, so it will further lead to the invalidation of the computed cache here.
